title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. It will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect ndash and the engagement with communities and staff will be a continuing process throughout the year. I look forward to getting back out to see staff from next week onwards.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Council budget to mark the start of reform
story: Highland Council has agreed sweeping changes to this yearrsquos annual budget of around pound million with the aim of not just balancing the books ndash with measures addressing a funding gap of almost pound million ndash but to instigate major reforms in how it provides services.Last Thursday, councillors debated, amended and approved its budget with policies including a three per cent rise in council tax and rising costs of funerals, cremations, commercial refuse collections and bulky uplts, while fees for emptying brown bins will go up by pound per year.Leisure and culture provider High Le Highlandcame out better than thought after the SNP negotiated a rise in membership cost of pound or less which took pound, off the original pound, proposed cut.But in a major sht from previous years the financial measures were targeted to reform services ndash particularly education ndash where millions of pounds of savings are being sought by improving performance.In another break with tradition, many of the proposals are dependant on further consultations with staff and the public.Cuts include funding for additional support needs ndash when a child needs more or dferent support to get the most from school ndash in what is a major shake-up of the service which some fear could be too much for the public to stomach.Chief executive Donna Manson said: ldquoI call it a budget for change. Education transformation ndash it is all about getting better outcomes.ldquoWe will work through that in the next three years. I am committed to doing that, but the key to it will be regular monitoring.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Cycle ride aims to help Highlands special needs charity
story: SUPPORTERS of a leline service for children and young adults with special needs are to take part in a sponsored cycle ride to raise desperately-needed funds.The Special Needs Action Projectis facing an uncertain future after Highland Council turned down the charityrsquos annual grant of pound, ndash  per cent of the total running costs of pound,.After hearing the charity might have to close, two members of Snaprsquos youth club decided to do something to help.Dean Stewart and Bradley Morrall, both aged , suggested a fundraiser and as a result, a sponsored cycle ride will be held on Saturday March  at the Highland Cycle Ability Centre at Cantraybridge.They and others aim to cycle  km by completing laps of the track.Deanrsquos mother Carol Macdonald said her son had attended Snap for many years.ldquoIt has enabled and encouraged him and many others to enjoy le, have fun, learn, grow and flourish with many dferent challenges, she said.ldquoSnap is a much-needed leline for children and young adults, families, siblings and carers.ldquoSnap is like a great big hug. It provides warmth, security, comfort, friendship and caring when needed.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Date set for Eastgate Hostel demolition
story: Provost Carmichael said: ldquoThis is a key city centre location which has for too long been blighted by scaffolding. The reinstatement of the High Street is a signicant improvement and I welcome the commitment madeby the owners to invest in this key site.The demolition news, which emerged this morning,is also supported by central ward councillors Janet Campbell, Bet McAllister and Richard Laird.In a joint statement they said: ldquoThis is welcome news especially for the businesses in the High Street. We are also pleased to see that the owners plan to liaise closely with businesses on the demolition work so as to minimise disruption.For more details and further reaction to the news see the next edition of the paper.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Focus on art of of sport in new Inverness exhibition
story: ART and shinty have become the perfect match for an exhibition that celebrates the culture and heritage of one of Scotlandrsquos oldest sports.The work ndash known as the Throw Up . project ndash is on show at Inverness Museum and Art Gallery until March .Organised by Invernessrsquos Highland Print Studio and funded by Highland Culture Strategic Boardrsquos Highland Culture: Take Pride, Take Part programme, four artists were commissioned to work with designated shinty clubs during  and into the  season.The artists have created a series of pieces that reflect their time spent getting to know the people involved in the clubs from players to volunteers to fans.Each artist used a iety of disciplines including photography, linocut, screen printing, photogravure and knitting.Cromarty artist John McNaught spent time with Skye Camanachd. He grew up in Skye and utilised his skills in printmaking and photography to produce mixed media prints celebrating the clubrsquos  years.Artist and former Lovat player Tom Smith worked with Beauly shinty club to develop an interactive piece showcasing three stories at a local, national and international level and through the use of augmented reality bring history to le.Highland Print Studio director Alison McMenemy said: ldquoThe whole project has been great and a huge learning experience.ldquoShinty is a unique sport and the level of commitment from the communities to running the clubs is quite remarkable.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness firm says Brexit is making customers cautious
story: UNCERTAINTY over the UKrsquos withdrawal from the European Union is causing people to delay home improvements according to an Inverness company.Cairngorm Windows has enjoyed its best start to a year in  years but managing director David Dowling says domestic customers are holding off finalising orders.ldquoPeople carrying out house improvements are approaching us but Brexit is delaying them from pressing the button he said.ldquoIn addition, our German fitted kitchen supplier have notied us of a . per cent import duty tax on all deliveries after March  in the absence of a deal going through.ldquoHowever, wersquove a record-breaking forward workbook thanks to the strong volume of orders from housebuilders while council contracts are at their highest level in  years.A pound, new computer operated cutting machine was fitted in January to drive forward Cairngormrsquos high-tech production process which saw a record , windows manufactured last year.The company aims to produce , windows this year and break the , barrier next year.Mr Dowling said housebuilders like Tulloch Homes, Springfield Homes, Compass and Scotframe had signicantly stepped up their forward orders while windows were being sold as far away as Swindon.Wersquove a strong domestic business where we supply and fit from fitted windows to fitted kitchens, he said.ldquoBut customers are currently telling us theyrsquore holding off the spend because of Brexit causing uncertainty to household budgets.ldquoWe hope that situation clears before too long.The company, which employs  people, installed a pound, automatic welder and corner cutter last year.It has been in business for  years.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness mentoring project aims to improve lives
story: AN INVERNESS mentoring programme is among the projects set to benefit from a pound million windfall for communities across the Highlands.Communities Secretary Aileen Campbell visited Charleston Academy as she announced the funding under the Scottish Governmentrsquos Aspiring Communities Fund.She met staff and pupils involved with a programme which sees young people mentor younger children at Kinmylies Primary School and Nursery.Charleston is one of nine Highland schools taking part in the Growinggether in the Community scheme run by Forres-based Ecologia Youth Trust which has been awarded pound,.During her visit, Ms Campbell heard from pupils how the scheme is helping to increase their wellbeing and confidence as well as strengthening community links.Jake Weston , who is among those who have taken part, mentored a young boy who was initially isolated from other children.ldquoHe was able to make friends and share lunch at the table with other children which he had not done previously, he said.ldquoI have gained a lot of confidence.Logan Parkersaid she had also grown in confidence.ldquoI would recommend it definitely ndash  per cent, she said.Ms Campbell said local communities understood what worked in their own areas and the funding would enable them to help create a more equal Scotland.ldquoIt will support organisations across the Highlands and Islands to deliver tangible, innovative approaches to improve lives based on local priorities and will address poverty and inequality in their area, she said.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Inverness pupils show winning ways in business competition
story: YOUNG business brains from across the Highlands were put to the test in a competition which sharpened their entrepreneurial skills and raised money for a deserving cause.Teams of six from local schools competed in the event organised by Highland Hospice.Secondary school pupils took each other on for the Young Highland Apprentice title, while primary children battled it out in their own junior event.The aim in both cases was to come up with a new product or service that could be sold to raise funds for the hospice.Pupils from Lochardil Primary School in Inverness triumphed in the junior category for their Rocks and Crosses game, a version of noughts and crosses using hand-painted rocks which comes with a gt bag that doubles up as the game board.Sales raised a total of pound. and saw the school crowned winners after a presentation at Inverness College UHI this week.Judges said they were impressed with their business acumen as well as their knowledge of the hospice and the work it does.Winning pound for their school courtesy of event sponsors Tailormade Moves, teacher Muriel Murray said: ldquoTheyrsquore delighted, really proud of themselves.ldquoItrsquos good to see their hard work recognised.In the older age category it was a team from Fortrose Academy who were triumphant, and Tain Royal Academy were runners-up.A team of fth years ran a whole iety of fundraising events between September and January that allowed them to present the hospice with a cheque for pound..Speaking about the impact of the competition as a whole, hospice community fundraiser Katie Gibb said: ldquoAs Highland Hospice is a vital service for the whole of the Highland community, this is a great way for us to raise awareness about our services within the younger generation.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: Last phase of Ness Islands work to take place next week
story: The final phase of improvement works on the Ness Islands is set to resume next week.Highland Councilrsquos city of Inverness area committee approved pound, of common good funding for improvement works on bridges, tree maintenance, pathways and bank erosion works, to take place in stages over  months.This final phase will start on Monday, concentrating on restructuring and repairing paths leading up to some of the bridges to enable smoother access for wheelchairs and prams.As part of this work the Wells Bridge will be closed for around a week.Other routes around the islands will still be accessible.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: New Nairn homes help meet demand
story: An affordable housing scheme in Nairn has welcomed its first residents, after Albyn Housing Society took handover of the development.The  new-build homes in Farnack Street have been allocated for affordable rent via the Highland Housing Register, providing much-needed accommodation for local applicants.This included a specially adapted property to support the needs of -year-old Shauni McCallum and her family.The new home is adapted to be wheelchair accessible, and also benefits from the inclusion of a large en-suite wet room with hoist provision and a carport.Her mother Myra Wardhaugh said: ldquoOur new home was specially adapted for Shaunirsquos requirements and we canrsquot even begin to express what a dference it has made.ldquoWe can now enjoy spending time in the home, as a family, without any added stress.Albyn Housing Society worked with contractor Springfield Properties to deliver the project in just  months.The new housing development represents a total investment of almost pound. million, with Scottish Government support totalling more than half that amount.Society chief executive Calum Macaulay said: ldquoWe have ambitious build plans for the coming years as we strive to meet growing demand for affordable homes.In the past year, the society has completed affordable housing developments in Inverness, Kirkhill, Alness and where.Tuesday  Feb  : PM

title: skipper left annoyed by dons poor run of home form
story: Club captain Graeme Shinnie today accepted Aberdeen’s Pittodrie slump is concerning and demanded an immediate improvement at home.The midfielder was left “annoyed” after the Reds’ home hurt continued with a dismal - draw with St Mirren, the side rock bottom of the Premiership table.Aberdeen had to fight back from a goal down twice to salvage a point against a struggling Buddies side who had lost six straight league matches.Scotland cap Shinnie did not pull his punches in his indictment of both his own performance and that of the Dons against the relegation battlers.“Not good enough,” he admitted.However, the concern is that it was not a one-off at Pittodrie as the Dons have taken just two points from the last  at home.Sandwiched amid that run was a - Scottish Cup draw against Stenhousemuir, bottom of Scotland’s third tier.With a Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against either Rangers or Kilmarnock on March , fixing the home form is a matter of urgency.Shinnie said: “The home form has been annoying and it is something we have to deal with.“We have not been good at home since the turn of the year and that is something we have to put right.“The form and the way we have played in the home games has not been good enough.“Stenhousemuir came up and got a draw .“Against Queen of the Southwe scored good goals in the second half but I don’t think we played overly great in the game.“Normally our home form is strong but recently it has not been good enough and that is something we have to put right.”Prior to the recent slump, Aberdeen had only dropped eight points at home all season – in  Premiership matches.Now they have dropped  in the last four league matches at Pittodrie.In contrast, the Dons’ form on the road – six straight wins – has kept them within touching distance of second-placed Rangers and still in the cup.Dropping points to the league’s bottom side was damaging, but the Dons did not lose any further ground on Rangers, who drew - with St Johnstone.Shinnie said: “At this stage in the season this has been a missed opportunity, with other results.“We need to get back to winning ways.”Midfielder Shinnie was uncharacteristically despondent after dropping points to St Mirren. He also refused to trot out any excuses for the result.He said: “We weren’t good enough. We need to be so much better as St Mirren are bottom of the table. When you score two goals at home you should be winning against the team that is bottom of the league.“I am annoyed at our performance as the first half wasn’t good enough. We didn’t move the ball about quick enough. We were slack in possession, from me especially.“It is not aswe played well, missed some good opportunities and were frustrated.“Throughout the team we were slack with the ball and St Mirren were comfortable in the way we were lacklustre and tried to get the tempo up.“We said we needed that tempo before the game but we didn’t do it. In the second half we then lost another goal, which is annoying and not good enough.“After that we were fighting to try to get back in the game.“Although we got the goal back, it didn’t really salvage anything.“At this stage of the season chances don’t come around too often. If we want to challenge right at the top then games like theseare ones you need to be winning.”Aberdeen suffered further disappointment at the weekend when defender Tommie Hoban was stretchered off in the first half with a knee injury.The on-loan Watford defender, , twisted awkwardly when attempting to change direction.Hoban was sidelined for the entirety of last season following surgery on a cruciate ligament injury, although the injury sustained at the weekend is to the other knee.Hoban had only recently ed for the Dons having been absent for five months following shoulder surgery in August.Shinnie said: “I am gutted for Tommie. He had done so well to get back to being fit again.“He has had such a good couple of weeks’ training and you could see the buzz in his eyes to be back involved and playing again.“To see that was devastating and I feel bad for him. I wish him well in his recovery and hopefully he can bounce back again.”The future of club captain Shinnie remains unresolved as the midfielder is out of contract at the end of the season.Aberdeen have offered the -year-old a lucrative new deal.A number of Championship clubs including Wigan Athletic, Hull City and Brentford have been monitoring Shinnie’s situation.Aberdeen boss Derek McInnes confirmed he had held fresh talks with the midfielder recently and had not given up hope of retaining Shinnie.McInnes hoped to have clarication, one way or another, over whether Shinnie was staying either this week or next.After the disappointment of dropping points to St Mirren, Shinnie was in no mood to discuss his future.He said: “After a game like that I have no thoughts on my contract situation.”

So we thought, while we#re doing that there#s other bits and pieces that we could be getting on with through the front.#Comfort and quiet is the aim of the cafe with new soft leather chairs and real wood tables absorbing noise and keeping everyone cosy and giving the cafe a luxurious feel.The fishing theme is still there. I got presents of these bits of wood. Duncan MacDonald gave me them about a year or two ago and one of the guys around here made them into fish boxes for me.#But Mhairi isn#t done yet.#We#re not actually  per cent finished. title: cairndow author at lochgilphead bookshop
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowOne of Argyll#s most dynamic social entrepreneurs has drawn on her Cairndow upbringing to write a truly fascinating book # and she will shortly be signing copies in Lochgilphead.Christina Noble used notes from her father#s journal and estate records, blending these with the recollections of the people of the estate to create Ardkinglas # the biography of a Highland estate.The book is a tale of the people, places and stories on Ardkinglas Estate since , when Christina#s great grandfather, industrialist Sir Andrew Noble, purchased the ,-acre property.Speaking at the book#s official launch in , she said: #Ardkinglas is a place that is very dear to me, and the place and the people have contributed to making me who I am today. It feels like home.#Christina, though, is never one to dwell too long on the past. In this book she has more than one eye on the future, asking pertinent questions about the potential for land use and communities as Scotland#s looks ahead.Having been one of the driving forces behind the creation of the #Here We Are# community enterprise at Clachan, Cairndow, she practices what she preaches. Now a store for a wealth of local memory and knowledge, Here We Are # situated beside the Tree Shop # hosts a post office and much more besides. It wasn#t long before Here We Are spawned  Our Power, a community energy business selling dried woodchip and with a stake in the Merk Hydro scheme in Glen Fyne. It is all about helping forge a sustainable future for rural communities.Saturday February  offers the chance to meet and have a chat with the author as she visits the Argyll Book Centre in Lochgilphead for a book signing between pm and pm.Refreshments will be available as you come along and have your copy signed.PIC:Christina Noble with a copy of her book. _aChristinaBook

title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

title: rest and be thankful mitigation project moves to next phase
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowThe next phase of the works to form landslide mitigation catch-pits next to the A at the Rest and Be Thankful is now underway.The £.M project started in spring  with works now continuing with the construction of the fourth catch-pit next to the road side.  These landslide mitigation measures involve the excavation of debris flow catch-pits next to the A.The catch-pits are designed to stop debris reaching the road from a landslide down the channels above each catch-pit location, helping to keep the A open.  Once completed, this fourth catch-pit will provide an additional , tonnes of debris storage capacity, bringing the total volume protection of the catch-pits to approximately , tonnes.In addition to the catch-pits, works on the additional protection measures at Glen Kinglas, approximately three miles from the Rest and Be Thankful, will continue.  The works at Glen Kinglas involve the re-use of the excavated rock from the Rest and be Thankful to form landslip mitigation bunds above streams along Glen Kinglas. The bunds will help reduce the risk of debris reaching the A in the event of a landslide.This project allows BEAR Scotland to maximise the benefit of recycling the material being excavated from the Rest and Be Thankful while minimising the overall cost of these works.To keep roadworkers and motorists safe throughout the works, temporary traffic lights will be in place on the A at each location. This next phase of the works is expected to last approximately  weeks.Commenting on the works, Eddie Ross, BEAR Scotland’s North West Representative said: #The installation of the next stages of the mitigation measures will provide more protection and resilience against any future landslips blocking this key route at both the Rest and Be Thankful and Glen Kinglas.#The temporary traffic lights are necessary to keep our teams as well as users of the route safe during the works, and the teams will do all they can to complete the project as quickly and safely as possible.#We encourage road users to plan their journeys in advance by checking the Traffic Scotland website for up to date travel information.#

title: human rights monitor philppa bonella speaks at ms centre
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowSt Margaret’s Justice and Peace Group invited Philppa Bonella to Lochgilphead on Tuesday February  to talk about her experiences as a human rights monitor on the Ecumenical Accompaniment Programme in Palestine and Israel .She was in the Holy Land for three months last year and spent time on the West Bank in Palestinian villages surrounded by Israeli settlements.Philippa told her audience that the EAPPI sends batches of people of all nationalities to the Holy Land for these three-month stints, where the monitors are split into small groups and must operate in pairs for safety.She recalled particular incidents – schools tear-gassed by Israeli troops, homes searched in raids during the middle of the night, families prevented from picking their olives, Palestinian villages surrounded by Israelis in mobile homes, supported by Israeli government-funded water and electricity supplies.Human rights monitors must be impartial and Philippa did her utmost to present a balanced picture and all EAPPI monitors share their findings and experiences with the UN with the intention of furthering solutions in this troubled region. Her conclusions drawn from experience was that when the monitors were around, there may have been unpleasant situations, but no tragedies. When there was no monitor around – clearly defined by their unorms – people died.Philippa had only been home for eight weeks when she spoke to the Justice and Peace Group, and she admitted that she was still processing the often brutal and violent scenes she had witnessed. And though she wryly joked that it had not exactly been a picnic, she encouraged her audience to become involved in the work of EAPPI – through prayer, support, even by volunteering to be a monitor .For more information, visit eappi.org en or visit the EAPPI Facebook page @EAPPI.WCCPIC:Her stories of the hardships in Israel kept visitors engaged. no_aholylandPhillipa Bonella speaking at the MS Centre. no_aholyland

Arthur Street Kitchen applied for permission to host live al fresco entertainment in the town centre. But councillors worried about noise want to carry out a site visit before making a decision. The venue’s manager Andy McPherson said: “We would like to have entertainment for customers in the garden this summer.” He said the music would not be too loud as the business is aware of residents living in the Arthur Street area of the town. Appearing before the South Ayrshire Council licensing board, he added: “We are hoping to reinvigorate Arthur Street. Ayr manager John Neil told the meeting no noise complaints were made last summer. The restaurant and pub also want to have a large screen to show sport and films. title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

story: NewsAyr United  Inverness : John Roberston hails Somerset Park among best grounds in worldThe Inverness gaffer was full of praise for the old fashioned surroundings as his side clung on in the face of a stirring fightback.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  JAN Updated:,  JAN NewsNathan Austin puts Caley - up "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJohn Robertson hailed Somerset Park as one of the best grounds in the WORLD after Caley held off a storming Ayr fightback. Inverness were three up and on easy street after a crazy opening  minutes which saw United gt-wrap the game. But a Lawrence Shankland inspired comeback almost grabbed a share of the spoils for Ian McCalls title contenders. A relieved Robertson said: Had it finished - you wouldnt have been surprised. Somerset Park is one of these grounds that sucks you inyou give them a snf. Its a good throwback and their fans make it intimidating and a good atmosphere for teams when you lose a goal. Its brilliant...one of the best grounds in the world to come and play your football. In the past we might have lost a game like this so Im delighted.  Ayr knew a win here would take them top of the Championship and started well with Robbie Crawford missing a good chance in the first minute. But they soon hit the self destruct button as their defence went AWOL to allow Nathan Austin in for a double before Liam Polworth rammed home a third. The game looked over with barely  minutes on the clock and shellshocked Ayr took time to regroup. Coventry-bound Michael Rose rocked the post with a header before Michael Moffat drew a fingertip save from Cammy Mackay. McCall turned to the bench at half time and introduced top gun Shankland who immediately turned the tide. He set up Declan McDaid to haul Ayr back into the contest with a close range finish eight minutes after the restart. And a resurgent Ayr thought they had a penalty when Carl Tremarco appeared to handle in the box but ref Nick Walsh waved away loud protests. United continued to pour forward as the clock ticked down and Shankland set up a grandstand finish when slamming home a  yard free kick with five minutes left.  But their comeback proved too little too late as Inverness clung on. Ayr boss McCall said: Im just gutted. Weve conceded three goals and at least two of them were gted with just crazy defending. And were the team with the best defensive record in the league. I think a draw would’ve been fair but it’s just one of those nights. title: centenary celebrations troons charles kerr
story: S pupils Abbie Rankine left and Neve Gooding at the bust of the founder Charles Kerr Marr."Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCharles Kerr Marr, retired coal contractor and formerly from Troon, boarded his train in London to Perthshire on Sunday January , , and little did he know his two week shooting and fishing break in Scotland would prove fatal for him, writes Nan McFarlane. His death revealed he had left his entire fortune in his will to his native town of Troon. His legacy would provide education awards and grants for the people of the town along with a new public school. As Marr’s train travelled north he decided to break his journey, to pay a visit to his sister in Girvan. He was close to his sister Helen and visited her often after her marriage to ColonelABGrant, owner of Killochan Castle estate at Girvan, who was also a senior partner in the firm of Grant Somerville  Co in London and was later ordained as Revd. Grant in the Church of Scotland. Marr had intended to spend part of his fortnight at Girvan but extended his stay to a month. Perhaps his change of heart was due to the widespread unrest taking place in Glasgow at that time. The January of  saw the so-called ‘Harbour Riots’, where racial confrontations were breaking out between black and white merchant seamen on the town’s quayside and spreading into the town. A four day General Strike was called for on January  and four days later George Square was crammed with tens of thousands of angry workmen. Crowds of unemployed men joined in the fracas for a  hour working week. As tempers flared the army was deployed, troops brought in tanks and armored vehicles to control the crowds. As tensions heightened it was not an environment travellers would want to find themselves caught up in. Eventually CK Marr left Girvan on Saturday February  for his onward journey north to his annual shooting and fishing break in Perthshire. As the train made its way towards the city he took ill with acute appendicitis. When taken off the train at the Central Station he was rushed to the Glasgow Nursing Home, but it was already too late as he tragically died in the operating theatre. There is little known of Charles Kerr Marr, despite having a successful career in the coal exporting business. Born on October , , at  Welbeck Crescent, Troon, he was the third son of Captain John Marr, master of the merchant ship ‘Reciprocity’, sailing between Troon and Canada. John Marr and his we Amelia had five children, sons William, John and Charles, along with two daughters, Helen and Amelia. Up to the age of ten, Charles attended the Parish School in Academy Street at Troon, going on to join his two brothers at Irvine Royal Academy to complete his education. On finishing his schooling, Marr was apprenticed at A  J Guthrie, Coal Agents at Troon Harbour. Unlike his brother John, who followed in his father’s footsteps to become a sea captain, Marr left home as soon as his apprenticeship ended, to work as a Commercial Clerk with Kitstons, Iron Merchants in Glasgow. Moving later to take up the position of cashier at Clyde Ironworks, only to leave a short time later to be manager of the firm of GrantSomerville  Co in London. The move may have been influenced by A B Grant, who was a senior partner in the company and married to his sister Helen. By the time he met his future we, some years later, there is no evidence as to when he moved back to Glasgow, or indeed any explanation found as to his change of occupation. Marr is recorded in the Scotland census of  as residing in Renfrew Street in Glasgow and again on his marriage certicate a year later, where he is also recorded as being employed as a Soft Goods Warehouseman.  Little is known as to why he left coal exporting to go into the Drapery business, or where he met and fell in love with his we Agnes Murray Kinghorn. However, Agnes’s father was a General Merchant, so it would seem likely he met her in his line of work. Charles and Agnes married on March ,  and set up home at Sutherland Terrace in Glasgow’s Hillhead. Unfortunately, after only  months of married le, Agnes tragically died of Phthisis Pulmonalis . She was just  years of age. Her death was a severe blow to Marr, leaving him brokenhearted and distraught, which had a profound effect on him. Shortly after he laid his we to rest, he had thought of going abroad to work, but instead accepted an appointment with Hull Blyth  Company of London. Within a year he was made a partner in the company when he developed the firm’s export trade. His work of establishing depots in numerous ports in the world gave him an opportunity to travel abroad, especially to China and Japan, where he found an interest in collecting oriental treasures. During his time with Hull Blyth the firm went on to become one of the largest shipping charterers in the UK. Charles Kerr Marr played a signicant part in the company’s worldwide success. Charles Marr moved to London after his we’s death, he never again owned a house. All his years in London, he alternated between two clubs, the Athenaeum and the Constitutional. The nearest he came to having a home was in his later years, when he rented two rooms in Camden House at Chislehurst in Kent, which was originally built for Napoleon the rd. Just being there helped him to relax and take up golf. He was reputed to be good company with a great sense of humour and well known to be very generous. Marr was a lover of the arts and music and in all that time he rarely spoke of his we, or of her death and he never remarried, even his closest friends assumed he was a bachelor. When he retired in  he spent a good part of each year fishing and shooting in Scotland. Two years before his untimely death, Charles Marr carefully drafted out his will in , leaving his entire fortune to the people of Troon and setting out the way it was to be carried out. Marr’s coal fortune legacy has given the town a magnicent architectural school building with playing fields the envy of the country. Marr College on its own is a fitting tribute to this man of extraordinary vision. By the time Marr College opened in  the school had attracted the most renowned academics to come and teach. It was the only grant aided school in Scotland that didn’t charge fees. A public school for every child of the town, had oak led class rooms, inlaid parquet flooring, Italian tiled corridorsa copper domed library, purple velvet drapes and teachers attired in flowing cloaks with mortar boards on their heads, this was seen by all to be a stunning,not magnicent, comprehensive school, deemed to be the best school in Scotland and envied by it. The CK Marr Educational Trust, the only one of its kind in Scotland, has provided awards or grants to hundreds of Troon students, of all ages each year. The addition of the MarrEducation Resource Centre in Troon Library, the only one then in Ayrshire, is a valuable educational resource for all who use it. Marr College and the CK Marr Educational Trust are a testimony to the wishes of Charles Kerr Marr and a fitting memorial to this great benefactor. He was buried beside his beloved we in CathcartCemetery in Glasgow. Over the past century the people of Troon owe a huge debt to custodians of Marr’s vision, the Marr Trustees, past and present. Over the decades the many Trustees, Boards of Governors and ious Clerks, Treasurers and Accountants, who have and still do today and for many decades to come, have successfully upheld the wishes of the town’s greatest ever benefactor and extraordinary visionary, Charles Kerr Marr.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnChurch of ScotlandUniversities and CollegesGlasgowEducationFishingArmed forcesLove and romanceSchoolsRenfrewTroonPerthshireGirvanAyr NewsAyr

title: junior football fans kept out
story: NewsJunior football fans kept out of the boozer before big matchThirsty Auchinleck Talbot fans forced to stay sober until nearer the kick-offShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThirst for football - Talbot fans at the match "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA lid was kept on football fan’s early hour boozing in the build up to the William Hill Scottish Cup Auchinleck Talbot game last month. A number of venues in the Auchinleck area applied to open their bars for a tipple at am on match day as Talbot geared up to face Ayr. Licensing bosses at East Ayrshire Council knocked back the flurry of applications for early morning drinking before the January  showdown. Despite the historic nature of the sporting event, the department decided to maintain their stance on trying to clamp down on excess boozing during football. The East Ayrshire Licensing board depute clerk Stuart McCall told councillors it was important to maintain the standard policy and have consistency. He pointed to Celtic and Rangers matches as examples of tense clashes requiring robust licensing rules. Mr McCall said: “The standard practice is games start early and the reason for that is to limit the amount of alcohol supporters can have.” “We all know the outcome excess alcohol can have in certain circumstances.” Congragulating Talbot, he added: “We are all delighted to see the result. “The maintenance of the policy is important so we are not accused of favouritism.” Some venues wanted to offer breakfast to supporters. Auchinleck Talbot defeated Ayr by one goal to nil. Alcohol was not permitted inside the grounds and fans were told they would be refused entryintoxicated. However the licensing board made a slight concession for the Auchinleck Talbot versus Hearts game on Sunday, February . story: NewsMeet the veteran vet now a towns Citizen of the YearHes now the Senior Citizen of the Year in CumnockShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA veteran vet has been named Cumnock Citizen of the Year. John Senior has been an animal surgeon in the town for  years. He has also immersed himself in activities and volunteering for all sorts of causes. This week he was continuing his latest community activity as a hand bell ringer at Cumnock Old Church. John, , said: “All I want is the best for Cumnock and we are so fortunte to have so many things going on now. “I just want to make it better than it is.” The Keir McTurk Memorial Committee chose John after “much deliberation” from all the nominations. Chairman Colin Chisholm said: “John is someone who prefers to work behind the scenes rather than be at the forefront. “But his efforts for the community have proved invaluable.” John, originally from Edinburgh, has freshly retired from the Crossriggs veterinary practice in the town. When he arrived in  it was chiefly large livestock but treats mostly small animals. His we Heather, also a vet, remains involved in the management and their son Iain, the third member of the Senior family who is a vet, runs the practice. John is a very active member of the Cumnock Action Plan Committee, in which he has reformed the Cumnock Gardening Club assisted living in the arrangements for the Christmas festival and was actively involved in the poppy display marking the centenary of the end of the First World War. He is also an elder in the Trinity Church and a member of the fabric committee. John is an active member of Cumnock Business Association, a board member of the credit union and of Glaisnock Trust and Cumnock Tryst. Assistance he gives to both the Highland games committee and Camps is described as “invaluable.” But he said: “I don’t like standing on a pedestal. I prefer being in the background. “I somehow manage to find time for the things I want to do and I am not very good at sitting down doing nothing. “I enjoy being active and putting things back into a town that has supported me and given me a living for  years.” The presentation is likely to be at Dumfries House. The couple also have a son Alan, a chemical engineer in Cleethorpes, and daughter Kirsty, who works in Christian outreach in Hong Kong.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnCumnockAyrAyr NewsEdinburghChristmasChristmas gtsReligion

title: volunteers bike tackle social isolation
story: NewsVolunteers get on their bike to tackle social isolationCycling Without Age Prestwick is transforming lives of those with limited mobility in the area with their specially designed trishaw, a light three -wheeled vehcile with pedal used in Asian countries.ShareByLochlin Highet:,  FEB NewsVolunteers get on their bike to tackle social isolation "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCommunity volunteers are coming together to tackle social isolation and loneliness - and their project is wheely fun. Cycling Without Age Prestwick is transforming lives of those with limited mobility in the area with their specially designed trishaw, a light three -wheeled vehcile with pedal used in Asian countries . The three-wheeled rickshaw is a little more than a ‘sofa on wheels’ as it is engineered to accommodate two passengers in the front and driven by a pilot in the rear. Those with mobility restrictions - old and young- can take a trip to the seafront, enjoy the Prestwick promenade views and have a good old natter. Now the community project, who’s base has been kindly gted by St Ninian’s Episcopal Church, are eager to find more volunteer pilots and those keen to get out on the trishaw. Chris Cheales, of Cycling Without Age Prestwick, said: “We now have two trishaws and we are in the middle of a training programme to help - people become qualied before starting the operation in spring. We offer two-hour sessions to two passengers and there is the opportunity to go for a drink, stop to chat, pet a dog or just enjoy the views. “We are looking for people with limited mobility who may or may not also struggle with loneliness and isolation and who would benefit from the freedom of feeling ‘the wind in their hair’. “Time is a wonderful gt to give anyone. The group hope to expand as the project grows and take their trishaws on tour to visit care homes in the area. Chris added: “We envisage days allocated to ‘user groups’, to include care homes, those recommended by Dementia Friendly Prestwick, retirement housing and local churches. “Trishaws are not cheap so we need ongoing help to keep all this on the road. “We are looking forward to another sunny summer and sharing the project with others.” The Prestwick Peoples Project has also benefitted those involved, helping volunteers flourish and gain confidence. Zara Crumlish has been a Young Ambassador for Cycling Without Age for six months. Zara, , said: “I’ve always wanted to ride a bike when I was younger but I didn’t have the balance. “The trishaw has helped me get my confidence up. “It gets me out and about with the community. “And I’m excited because I really can’t wait to take elderly people out and show them the Prom.” •Would you like to be trained as a Trishaw Pilot  Or a willing volunteer to be a co-pilot to accompany trips  . Contact cyclingwithoutageprestwick@gmail for more information.
